column5: Time to make jerky for the trip. What is your favorite recipe? Here is mine: 1 1/2 to 2 pounds of lean critter meat 2/3 cup Worcestershire sauce 2/3 cup soy sauce 2 teaspoons ground black pepper 2 teaspoons onion powder 1 teaspoon liquid smoke 2 teaspoon red pepper flakes 1 tablespoon honeyCut back on the red pepper flacks if you don't like it hot. Slice the meat with the grain about 1/4 inch strips. Mix brine ingredients in a gallon ziploc bag. Place meat strips in brine. Move the meat around so the marinade is evenly distributed around it. Seal bag, working out as much air as possible. Lay bag flat and refrigerate for 3 to 6 hours. Drain the strips and place on drying racks. Place racks in front of box fan in a cool place and dry for 12 to 15 hours. It's ready when the strips crack when you bend them.I don't use heat when drying. Just a couple of box fans and drying racks. Even on low heat it melts the fat and really changes the taste.I got this recipe from Alton Brown's Good Eats show.

I actually make hamburger jerky. I use the a spice pack from Cabelas where I mix it with the hamburger, let it sit overnight, use a jerky press to press out strips onto the dehydrator. It' sreally good and tender.

[QUOTE=Walleye_Wrangler;1436149]Time to make jerky for the trip. What is your favorite recipe? Here is mine: 1 1/2 to 2 pounds of lean critter meat 2/3 cup Worcestershire sauce 2/3 cup soy sauce 2 teaspoons ground black pepper 2 teaspoons onion powder 1 teaspoon liquid smoke 2 teaspoon red pepper flakes 1 tablespoon honey I use the same basic recipe as yours but sprinkel course ground pepper on the meat after putting on the rack before drying. My next batch I'm going to put into Bradly Digital smoker with only about 1 hour of hickory smoke at 180deg and continue heat until dry. This makes me hungry, have to start batch tonight.
Walleye_Wrangler,When you say no heat,does it give it a bad taste?As JJJMN, I also have a Bradley smoker,and was thinking the same thing about smoking it alittle before?

No, it doesn't taste bad. Just tastes different. Fat starts to renders at about 100-115F. When you use heat to dry the jerky it renders the fat in the meat and you get a different flavor. You can really tell the difference. It even looks different.I'm going to try and use real smoke at low temperature. I just haven't came up with a good way of doing it .
Please post how you do,I can smoke with no heat except for what heats the brickquette but I still think it would be above 100,if I recall its about 120ish
My recipe: pick some up at the gas station for the drive up. Once at camp, diet switches to fish and potatoes for several days.

For those traveling through Wisconsin I-90/94,take exit hwy 33 west to Baraboo 10 min.or so from the interstate,just before you get into town there is a meat market called Hart & Vold on the left side by the fairgrounds,the best you will ever try!$20/lb. and sometimes i'll pick up 5lb. it's that good.And Ten Horse, I alway stop in Minong on the way back and pick up 8-10lb.of Jack Links.
